metadata.title: A transcriptional regulatory atlas of coronavirus infection of 1 human cells USA

abstract.text: Identifying transcriptional responses that are most consistently associated with 16 experimental coronavirus (CoV) infection can help illuminate human cellular signaling 17 pathways impacted by CoV infection. Here, we distilled over 3,000,000 data points from 18 publically archived CoV infection transcriptomic datasets into consensus regulatory 19 signatures, or consensomes, that rank genes based on their transcriptional 20 responsiveness to infection of human cells by MERS, SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2 21 subtypes. We computed overlap between genes with elevated rankings in the CoV 22 consensomes against those from transcriptomic and ChIP-Seq consensomes for nearly 23 880 cellular signaling pathway nodes. Validating the CoV infection consensomes, we 24 identified robust overlap between their highly ranked genes and high confidence targets 25 of signaling pathway nodes with known roles in CoV infection. We then developed a 26 series of use cases that illustrate the utility of the CoV consensomes for hypothesis 27 generation around mechanistic aspects of the cellular response to CoV infection. We 28 make the CoV infection datasets and their universe of underlying data points freely 29 accessible through the Signaling Pathways Project web knowledgebase at 30 https://www.signalingpathways.org/datasets/index.jsf. : bioRxiv preprint Josset et al., 2013; Sims et al., 2013; Yoshikawa et al., 2010). To date however the field 56 has lacked a resource that fully capitalizes on these datasets by, firstly, using them to 57 rank human genes according to their transcriptional response to CoV infection and 58 secondly, contextualizing these transcriptional responses by integrating them with 59 'omics data points relevant to host cellular signaling pathways. Here, as a service to the 60 research community to catalyze the development of novel CoV therapeutics, we 61 generated consensomes for infection of human cells by MERS, SARS1 and SARS2 62 CoVs. We then analyzed the extent to which high confidence transcriptional targets for 63 these viruses intersected with genes with elevated rankings in transcriptomic and ChIP-64 Seq consensomes for cellular signaling pathway nodes. Integration of the CoV 65 consensomes with the existing universes of SPP transcriptomic and ChIP-Seq data 66 points in a series of use cases illuminates previously uncharacterized intersections 67 between CoV infection and human cellular signaling pathways. The CoV infection 68 consensome and its underlying datasets provide researchers with a unique and freely 69 accessible framework within which to generate and pressure test hypotheses around 70 human cellular signaling pathways impacted by CoV infection. : bioRxiv preprint 93 transcription factor (Supplementary information, Section 2, columns W-Z). As an initial 94 benchmark for the ALL CoV consensome, we assembled a list of 20 interferon-95 stimulated genes (ISGs), which encode many of the key canonical viral response 96 factors (Supplementary information, Section 2, column I) (Schneider et al., 2014). As

Generation of the CoV consensomes 76 We first set out to generate a set of consensomes ranking human genes based on the 77 frequency of their significant differential expression in response to infection by MERS, infection transcriptomic datasets (Supplementary information, Section 1). Using these 84 curated datasets, we next generated consensomes for each CoV species, as well as 85 one ranking genes across all CoV infection experiments (ALL CoV). As a reference 86 consensome for a virus whose transcriptional impact on human cells has been studied 87 in depth, we also generated a consensome for human influenza A virus (IAV) infection. 88 The Supplementary information files contain the full human ALL CoV (Section 2), MERS 89 (Section 3), SARS1 (Section 4), SARS2 (Section 5) and IAV (Section 6) infection 7 for the complete numerical data. We next surveyed the significant overlaps to identify 120 . CC-BY 4.0 International license was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. It is made available under a (Haviv et al., 1998) . FIGREF0.text: 36 pathway nodes. These include chemokine and cytokine-activated receptors, signaling 37 enzymes and transcription factors, and the genomic targets encoding their downstream 38 effectors (Takeda et al., 2003; Stark et al., 1998; Darnell et al., 1994)]. We recently 39 described the Signaling Pathways Project (SPP; (Ochsner et al., 2019), an integrated 40 'omics knowledgebase designed to assist bench researchers in leveraging publically 41 archived transcriptomic and ChIP-Seq datasets to generate research hypotheses. A 42 unique aspect of SPP is its collection of consensus regulatory signatures, or 43 consensomes, which rank genes based on the frequency of their significant differential 44 expression across transcriptomic experiments mapped to a specific signaling pathway 45 node or node family. By surveying across multiple independent datasets, we have 46 shown that consensomes recapitulate pathway node-genomic target regulatory 47 relationships to a high confidence level (Ochsner et al., 2019). 48 Placing the transcriptional events associated with human CoV infection in context with 49 those associated with other signaling paradigms has the potential to catalyze the 50 development of novel therapeutic approaches. The CoV research community has been 51 active in generating and archiving transcriptomic datasets documenting the 52 transcriptional response of human cells to infection by the three major CoV species, 53 namely, Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS) and severe acute 54 respiratory syndrome coronaviruses 1 (SARS1) and 2 (SARS2) (DeDiego et al., 2011; 55 .

FIGREF1.text: CoVs. To do this we searched the Gene Expression Omnibus 79 (GEO) and ArrayExpress databases to identify datasets involving infection of human 80 cells by these species. From this initial collection of datasets, we next carried out a 81 three step quality control check as previously described (Ochsner et al., 2019), yielding 82 a total of 3,041,047 million data points in 111 experiments from 25 independent CoV83

FIGREF2.text: 90 transcriptomic consensomes. To assist researchers in inferring transcriptional regulation 91 of signaling networks, the ALL CoV consensome is annotated to indicate the identity of 92 a gene as encoding a bioactive small molecule, receptor, signaling enzyme or 6 shown in the scatterplot representation of the ALL COV consensome in Figure 1, all 98 canonical ISGs were assigned appropriately elevated rankings in the consensome. 99 To gain insight into transcriptional intersections between CoV infection and human 100 cellular signaling pathways, we next computed genes with elevated rankings in the CoV 101 consensomes against genes with high confidence regulatory relationships with cellular 102 signaling pathway nodes. To do this we generated five lists of genes corresponding to 103 the ALL CoV, MERS, SARS1, SARS2 and IAV transcriptomic consensome 95 th 104 percentiles. We then retrieved genes in the 95 th percentiles of human transcriptomic (n 105 = 30) consensomes and ChIP-Seq (n = 834) consensomes for a collection of cellular 106 signaling pathway nodes, and computed the extent and significance of their overlap with 107 genes in the 95 th percentiles of each of the five CoV consensomes. Significant overlap 108 between the 95 th percentiles of a node/node family consensome and a CoV 109 consensome would indicate a potential biological relationship between loss or gain of 110 function of that node and the transcriptional response to CoV infection. 111 For clarity and brevity we will refer from here on to the 95 th percentile of a ChIP-Seq 112 consensome as "CC95" and the 95 th percentile of a transcriptomic consensome as 113 "TC95". Of the 834 node CC95s evaluated, 377 had significant overlap (p < 0.05) with at 114 least one of the CoV infection TC95s; of the 30 node/node family TC95s evaluated, 25 115 had significant overlap (p< 0.05) with at least one of the CoV infection TC95s. Results of 116 these analyses are shown in Figure 2 (receptor and enzyme transcriptomic analysis), ChIP-Seq transcription factor analysis), Figure 4 (ChIP-Seq enzyme analysis) 118 and Figure 5 (ChIP-Seq co-node analysis); see also Supplementary information Section

FIGREF4.text: Reflecting their well-documented roles in the response to viral infection, we 125 observed appreciable significant overlap between all TC95s and those for the toll-like 126 (TLR (Totura et al., 2015), interferon (IFNR (Hensley et al., 2004)) and tumor necrosis 127 factor (TNFR (W. Wang et al., 2007)) receptor families (Fig. 2). Interestingly, these 128 signatures were particularly highly enriched in the SARS2 TC95 -potentially reflecting a 129 particularly strong antiviral response to infection by SARS2. TC95 overlaps for receptor 130 systems with previously uncharacterized connections to CoV infection, including 131 epidermal growth factor receptors, glucocorticoid receptor and NOTCH receptor 132 signaling, are consistent with the known roles of these receptor systems in the context 133 of other viral infections (Hayward, 2004; Ito et al., 2011; Ng et al., 2013; Ostler et al., 134 2019; Zheng et al., 2014). The relatively strong enrichment for xenobiotic receptors 135 reflects work describing a role for pregnane X receptor in innate immunity (S. Wang et 136 al., 2014) and points to a potential role for members of this family in the response to 137 CoV infection.

FIGREF5.text: Transcription factors In general, ChIP-Seq enrichments for transcription factors and139 other nodes were more specific for individual CoV infection TC95s (compare Fig. 2 with 140 Figs 3, 4 and 5). This is likely due to the fact that ChIP-Seq consensomes are based on 141 direct promoter binding by a specific node antigen, whereas transcriptomic 142 consensomes encompass both direct and indirect targets of specific receptor and 143 .

FIGREF6.text: Compared to the roles of receptors and transcription factors in the response 156 to viral infection, the roles of signaling enzymes are less well illuminated -indeed, CDK9, is a member of the viral-targeted p-TEFB complex (Zaborowska et al., 170 2016). Reflecting a potential general role in viral infection, appreciable overlap was 171 observed between the CCNT2 CC95 and all viral TC95s (Fig. 4). Finally in the context 172 of enzymes, DNA Topoisomerase (TOP1) has been shown to be required for efficient 173 replication of simian virus 40 (Wobbe et al., 1987) and Ebola (Takahashi et al., 2013) 174viruses. The prominent overlap between its CC95 and those of SARS2 and IAV(Fig. 4)175 suggest that it may play a similar role in facilitating the replication of these viruses.

FIGREF7.text: Co-nodesWe have coined the term "co-nodes" as a convenient catch-all for cellular 177 factors that are not members of the three principal signaling pathway node categories178 (receptors, enzymes and transcription factors; Ochsner et al., 2019). The breadth of 179 functions encompassed by members of this category reflects the diverse mechanisms 180 employed both by viruses to infect and propagate in cells, as well as by hosts to mount 181 an efficient immune response. Consistent with its characterized role in the recruitment 182 of p-TEFB by IV-1 Tat protein (Schulze-Gahmen et al., 2013), we observed consistently 183 strong enrichment of the AFF4 CC95 in all viral TC95s (Fig. 5). The targeting of CNOT3 184 for degradation in response to adenoviral infection (Chalabi Hagkarim et al., 2018) is 185reflected in the significant overlap between its CC95 and the viral TC95s, particularly in 186 the case of the SARS2(Fig. 5).

FIGREF8.text: By way of additional independent validation of the CoV and IAV consensomes, Gene188 Set Enrichment Analysis (Subramanian et al., 2005) reflected significant overlap the reliability of the consensome approach in the context of CoV 194 infection, we next wished to use the CoV consensomes to gather evidence to identify 195 previously uncharacterized mediators of the transcriptional response to infection by 196 CoVs and, of particular current interest, SARS2.

FIGREF9.text: 1: consensome redundancy analysis identifies potential 199 uncharacterized players in the response to CoV infection 200 We previously showed (Figs. 2 and 3) that the overlap of the CoV TC95 genes was 201 most robust among consensomes for members of the IFNR, TLR and TNF receptor 202 families (Fig. 2), and the NFkB, RELA, IRF and STAT transcription factor families (fig. 203 5). To investigate this further, we ranked genes in the ALL CoV consensome by their 204 aggregate 80 th percentile rankings across these consensomes (Supplementary 205 information, Section 2, column V). Transcriptomic consensomes for IFNRs (Section 9), 206 TLRs (Section 10) and TNFRs (Section 11) are provided in Supplementary information, 207 as are links to the ChIP-Atlas lists used to generate the ChIP-Seq consensomes 208 (Section 12).

FIGREF10.text: ranking elevates genes with known critical roles in the response to 210 viral infection that are acutely responsive to a spectrum of inflammatory signaling 211 nodes, such as NCOA7 (Doyle et al., 2018), STAT (Chapgier et al., 2009) and TAP1 212 (Gruter et al., 1998). Interestingly, genes such as PSMB9, CSRNP1 and MRPL24 have 213 ALL CoV discovery rates that are comparable to or exceed those of many of the classic 214 viral response ISGs (Fig. 1), but are either largely or completely uncharacterized in the 215 context of viral infection. This use case the reflects the potential of consensome-driven 216 data mining to illuminate novel and potentially therapeutically relevant transcription 217 pathway effectors in the response to CoV infection.

FIGREF12.text: 222characteristic of CoV infection but not IAV infection. To do this we generated a set of 223 genes that were frequently differentially expressed in response to CoV infection (ALL 224 CoV TC99), but less frequently expressed in response to IAV infection (50 th percentile)Table 1). Interestingly, this group contained two genes encoding transcription factors226    with well characterized roles in the regulation of oscillatory gene expression, PER1 and 227 PER2(Yamajuku et al., 2010). This led us to speculate that genomic targets of 228 transcriptional regulators of circadian rhythms might be enriched among high 229 confidence CoV-regulated genes, but not IAV-regulated genes. Consistent with this we230 observed significant overlap between the CC95s of the master circadian transcription 231 factors ARNTL1/BMAL1 and CLOCK (Gaucher et al., 2018) and the CoV TC95, but not signaling and the cellular oscillatory apparatus. Another gene of note in 234 this group is INHBA, encoding activin A, overexpression of which in murine lung gives 235 rise to a phenotype resembling acute respiratory distress-like syndrome (Apostolou et 236 al., 2012), a condition commonly associated with CoV infection (Totura & Bavari, 2019). 237 Other genes in the group provide evidence for the potential mechanisms of infection 238 and propagation of CoVs. TJAP1, for example, encodes a member of a family of 239 proteins involved in regulation of tight junctions, shown to be route of porcine epidemic 240 diarrhea coronavirus entry into epithelial cells (Luo et al., 2017). In addition, GON7 is a 241 member of the KEOPS complex (Wan et al., 2017), which is involved in 242 threonylcarbamoylation of tRNAs, which represent an important host facet of the 243 retroviral life cycle (Jin & Musier-Forsyth, 2019). Interestingly, another critical gene in 244 this tRNA pathway, YRDC, is the 19 th ranked gene in the ALL CoV consensome 245 (Supplementary information Section 2). 246 247 Use case 3: evidence for antagonism between progesterone receptor and 248 interferon receptor signaling in the airway epithelium 249 Although a lack of clinical data has so far prevented a definitive evaluation of the 250 connection between pregnancy and susceptibility to SARS2 infection in COVID-19, 251 pregnancy has been previously associated with the incidence of viral infectious 252 diseases, particularly respiratory infections (Sappenfield et al., 2013; Siston et al., 253 2010). We were interested therefore to see consistent overlap between the 254 progesterone receptor (PGR) TC95 and all the viral TC95s, with the enrichment being the crosstalk implied by this overlap in the context of the airway epithelium, we 257 first identified a set of 16 genes that were in both the ALL CoV and PGR TC95s. We 258 then retrieved two SPP experiments involving treatment of A549 airway epithelial cells 259 with the PGR full antagonist RU486 (RU), alone or in combination with the GR agonist 260 dexamethasone (DEX). As shown in Figure 6 , there was nearly unanimous correlation 261 in the direction of regulation of all 16 genes in response to CoV infection and PGR loss 262 of function. These data indicate that antagonism between PGR and IFNR signaling in 263 the airway epithelium may predispose pregnant women to infection by SARS2. 264 265 Use case 4: evidence for a role for the telomerase catalytic subunit TERT in the 266 interferon response to viral infection 267 Although telomerase activation has been well characterized in the context of cell 268 immortalization by human tumor virus infection (Gewin et al., 2004; Klingelhutz et al., 269 1996; Yang et al., 2004), no connection has previously been made between CoV or IAV 270 infection and telomerase. We were therefore intrigued to observe robust overlap 271 between all viral TC95s and that of the telomerase catalytic subunit TERT. In support of 272 this finding, NFkB signaling has been shown to induce expression (Yin et al., 2000) and 273 nuclear translocation (Akiyama et al., 2003) of TERT, and direct co-regulation by 274 telomerase of NFkB-dependent transcription has been linked to chronic inflammation 275 (Ghosh et al., 2012). Inspecting the ALL CoV consensome underlying data points (data 276 not shown) we found that the TERT gene was not transcriptionally induced in response 277 to infection by any of the CoVs, indicating that the overlap between its TC95 and those CoVs might occur in response to an upstream regulatory signal. If functional 279 interactions between TERT and inflammatory nodes did indeed take place in response 280 to CoV infection, we anticipated that this would be reflected in close agreement 281 regarding the direction of differential expression of CoV infection-regulated genes in 282 response to perturbation of TERT on the one hand, and on the other, to stimulation of 283 the classic viral response IFNRs. To test this hypothesis, we took the same set of 20 284 ISGs referred to previously (Fig. 1) and compared their direction of regulation across all 285 experiments underlying the ALL CoV, TERT and IFNR consensomes. For reference, the 286 TERT consensome (Section 13) and its underlying data points (Section 14) are 287 provided in the Supplementary information. With respect to the IFNR and TERT data 288 points, we observed a nearly universal alignment in the direction of regulation of all 289 genes tested with those in the CoV infection experiments (Fig. 6), with agreement in the 290 direction of regulation across 99% of the underlying probesets. We should note that of 291 the 1859 p < 0.05 CoV infection ISG data points, we observed repression, rather than 292 induction, in response to CoV infection in 303 (~15%) , which may be attributable to the 293 impact of differences in cell type, cell cycle stage or virus incubation time across the 294 independent experiments. Our results are consistent with a model in which activation of 295 telomerase is a component of the human innate immune response to viral infection.

FIGREF13.text: 5: SARS2 infection of human cells is specifically associated with an298 epithelial to mesenchymal transition transcriptional signature 299 Epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) is the process by which epithelial cells lose 300 their polarity and adhesive properties and acquire the migratory and invasive Adair & Ledermann, 2020; P. Zhou et al., 2020). Moreover, EMT is widely 305 accepted as a core component of the process by which renal tubular cells transform into 306 mesenchymal cells during the development of fibrosis in kidney disease (Y. Liu, 2006), 307 a signature comorbidity of SARS2 infection (Durvasula et al., 2020). Of the 834 CC95s 308 analyzed, overlap (p < 0.05) was specific to the SARS2 CC95 for only five; SNAI2/Slug, 309 SOX2, GATA6, CTBP1 and PRMT1. Strikingly, a literature search indicated that these 310 five nodes were connected by documented roles in in the promotion of EMT (Avasarala 311 et al., 2015; Herreros-Villanueva et al., 2013; Martinelli et al., 2017; Nieto, 2002; Sahu 312 et al., 2017). In addition to these nodes, whose C95 genes were exclusively enriched (p 313 < 0.05) in the SARS2 C95 genes, we identified several other EMT-linked nodes whose 314 CC95 genes were preferentially enriched (p < 0.05) in the SARS2 TC95 genes (Figs. 3-315 5), including the homeodomain transcription factor SIX2 (C.-A. Wang et al., 2014), 316 SMAD4 (Siraj et al., 2019), and the co-nodes PYGO2 (Chi et al., 2019), SKI (Tecalco-317 Cruz et al., 2018), BRD7 (T. Liu et al., 2017) and STAG2 (Nie et al., 2019). 318 To investigate this further, we computed overlap between the individual viral TC99s and 319 a list of 335 genes manually curated from the research literature as signature EMT 320 markers (Supplementary information Section 15; Zhao et al., 2015). Consistent with the 321 node consensome enrichment analysis, we observed significant enrichment of 322 members of this gene set within the SARS2 CC99, but not those of the ALL CoV, 323 SARS1, MERS or IAV consensomes (Supplementary information Section 16). therefore, we next calculated airway epithelial cell-specific consensomes for 328 SARS1 and MERS and computed overlap of their TC95s against the 864 pathway 329 node/node family CC95s & TC95s. We found that significant overlap with the CoV330

FIGREF14.text: 333SARS2 regulated genes (CPV P < 0.05) that were high confidence targets (i.e. in the 334 CC80) for at least two of the EMT nodes (SNAI2, SOX2, GATA6, CTBP1 and PRMT1;335    Supplementary information, Section 4, column M). A literature survey showed that 13 of 336 these 21 genes had a documented connection to EMT (Supplementary information, 337 Section 5, column N).Figure 9compares the percentile rankings for these genes across 338 the three CoV infection consensomes and the IAV consensome. Although some EMT 339 genes, such as CXCL2 and IRF9, had elevated rankings across all four consensomes, 340 the collective EMT gene signature had a significantly higher mean percentile value in 341 the SARS2 consensome than in each of the three others(Fig. 9).342 Although EMT has been associated with infection by transmissible gastroenteritis virus 343 (Xia et al., 2017), this is to our knowledge the first evidence connecting CoV infection, 344 and specifically SARS2 infection, to EMT. Interestingly, several members of the group 345 of SARS2-induced EMT genes have been associated with signature pulmonary 346 comorbidities of CoV infection, including ADAR (Diaz-Pina et al., 2018)Vukmirovic et al., 2017) and SOD2 (Gao et al., 2008). Of note in the context of these 348 data is the fact that signaling through two SARS2 cellular receptors, ACE2/AT2 and 349 CD147/basigin, has been linked to EMT in the context of organ fibrosis (Kato et al., 350 2011; Ruster & Wolf, 2011; C. Wang et al., 2018). Moreover, overlap between of the 351 CoV TC95s and the TERT CC95 was particularly robust in the case of SARS2, a finding 352 of potential relevance to the fact that telomerase has been implicated in EMT (Z. Liu et 353 al., 2013). Collectively, our data indicate that EMT warrants further investigation as a 354 SARS2-specific pathological mechanism. 355 Development of a CoV infection cell signaling knowledgebase 356 Having validated the ALL CoV consensome, we next wished to make it freely available 357 to the research community for re-use in the characterization of signaling events 358 associated with CoV infection. Firstly, the viral infection datasets were curated 359 accordingly to our previously described protocol (Ochsner et al., 2019) made available 360 for browsing in the SPP Dataset listing 361 (https://www.signalingpathways.org/datasets/index.jsf). As with other SPP datasets, and 362 per FAIR data best practice, CoV infection datasets were associated with detailed 363 descriptions, assigned a digital object identifier, and linked to the associated article to 364 place the dataset in its original experimental context. Loading the CoV datasets into the 365 SPP also automatically made the underlying data points discoverable by the SPP query 366 tool Ominer (Ochsner et al., 2019). These reports represent a summary of the current 367 state of transcriptomic and ChIP-Seq knowledge on the regulatory relationship of a 368 given gene with upstream regulatory pathway nodes, or in clinical and model 369 experiments. The full value of the integration of the CoV consensome with the existing can perhaps be best appreciated in the context of the one click links to 371 Ominer Regulation Reports from the individual CoV datasets. These Reports provide 372 researchers with a wealth of contextual data on signaling pathways impacted by CoV 373 infection in the context of a specific gene. Table 2 shows links to Regulation Reports for 374 the top twenty ranked genes in the ALL CoV consensome. The order of sections in the 375 Reports is Receptors, Enzymes, Transcription Factors, Co-nodes, Clinical and Models, 376 the last section including data points from the CoV infection model experiments that 377 form the basis of this study.

FIGREF15.text: research community response to the impact of CoVs on human health 380 demands systematic exploration of the transcriptional interface between viral infection 381 and human cell signaling systems. It also demands routine access to existing datasets 382 that is unhindered either by paywalls or by lack of the informatics training required to 383 manipulate archived datasets in their unprocessed state. Moreover, the substantial 384 logistical obstacles to BSL3 certification only emphasizes the need for fullest possible 385 access to, and re-usability of, existing CoV infection datasets to focus and refine 386 hypotheses prior to carrying out in vivo CoV infection experiments. To this end, we 387 generated a set of CoV infection consensomes that rank human genes by the 388 reproducibility of their significant differential expression in response to infection of 389 human cells by CoVs. We then computed the CoV consensomes against high 390 confidence transcriptional signatures for a broad range of cellular signaling pathway 391 nodes, affording investigators with a broad range of signaling interests an entrez into 392 the study of CoV infection of human cells. The five use cases described here represent 393 illustrative examples of the types of analyses that users are empowered to carry out in 394 the CoV infection knowledgebase. 395 To democratize access to the CoV consensome and its >3,000,000 underlying data 396 points by the broadest possible audience, we have integrated them into the SPP 397 database to create a cell signaling knowledgebase for CoV infection. Incorporation of 398 the CoV data points into SPP in this manner places them in the context of millions more 399 existing SPP data points documenting transcriptional regulatory relationships between 400 pathway nodes and their genomic targets. In doing so, we afford users a unique

FIGREF16.text: 405 will be particularly important in the case of SARS2, as datasets involving infection of 406 human cells with this virus are necessarily currently limited in number. This will allow 407 for hardening of observations that are intriguing, but whose significance is currently 408 unclear, such as the overlap of the CoV TC95s with the TERT TC95, as well as the 409 enrichment of EMT genes among those with elevated rankings in the SARS2 410 consensome. We welcome feedback and suggestions from the research community for 411 the future development of the SPP CoV infection consensomes.

FIGREF17.text: values were calculated for each gene in each experiment using 420 the limma analysis package from Bioconductor then committed to the consensome 421 analysis pipeline as previously described (Ochsner et al., 2019). Briefly, the 422 consensome algorithm surveys each experiment across all datasets and ranks genes 423 according to the frequency with which they are significantly differentially expressed. For 424 each transcript, we counted the number of experiments where the significance for 425 differential expression was ≤0.05, and then generated the binomial probability, referred 426 to as the consensome p-value (CPV), of observing that many or more nominally 427 significant experiments out of the number of experiments in which the transcript was 428 assayed, given a true probability of 0.05. A more detailed description of the 429 transcriptomic consensome algorithm is available (Ochsner et al., 2019). The 430 consensomes and underlying datasets were loaded into an Oracle 13c database and 431 made available on the SPP user interface as previously described (Ochsner et al., 432 2019).

FIGREF18.text: ) implemented in R. Briefly, given a whole set I of IDs and two sets A ∈ I and B ∈ I, 438 and S = A ∩ B, GeneOverlap calculates the significance of obtaining S. The problem is test. The universe for the overlap was set at a recent estimate of the total 441 number of coding genes in the human genome (21,500; Pertea et al., 2018). Paired 442 Two Sample t-Test for comparing the mean percentile ranking of EMT genes in the 443 MERS, SARS1, SARS2 and IAV consensomes was performed in PRISM at 12 degrees 444 of freedom.

FIGREF19.text: for generating transcriptomic consensomes has been previously 447 described (Ochsner et al., 2019). To generate the ChIP-Seq consensomes, we first 448 retrieved processed gene lists from ChIP-Atlas, which rank human genes based upon 449 their average MACS2 occupancy across all publically archived datasets in which a 450 given transcription factor, enzyme or co-node is the IP antigen. Of the three stringency 451 levels available (10, 5 and 1 kb from the transcription start site), we selected the most 452 stringent (1 kb). According to SPP convention (Ochsner et al., 2019), we then mapped 453 the IP antigen to its pathway node category and class, and the experimental cell line to 454 its appropriate biosample physiological system and organ. We then organized the 455 ranked lists into percentiles to generate the node ChIP-Seq consensome. 456 SPP web application 457 The SPP knowledgebase is a gene-centric Java Enterprise Edition 6, web-based 458 application around which other gene, mRNA, protein and BSM data from external 459 databases such as NCBI are collected. After undergoing semiautomated processing 460 and biocuration as described above, the data and annotations are stored in SPP's are the primary technologies behind the user interface. SPP has been 465 optimized for Firefox 24+, Chrome 30+, Safari 5.1.9+, and Internet Explorer 9+, with 466 validations performed in BrowserStack and load testing in LoadUIWeb. XML describing 467 each dataset and experiment is generated and submitted to CrossRef to mint DOIs 468 (Ochsner et al., 2019).

FIGREF20.text: set of data points used to generate the CoV consensome has been uploaded in an R 472 file to Figshare and a link included for reviewer access. The entire set of metadata for these 473 data points is available in Supplementary information Section 1. Consensome data points are in 474 Supplementary information Sections 2-6. 475 SPP is freely accessible at https://www.signalingpathways.org. Programmatic access to all 476 underlying data points and their associated metadata are supported by a RESTful API at 477 https://www.signalingpathways.org/docs/. All SPP datasets are biocurated versions of publically 478 archived datasets, are formatted according to the recommendations of the FORCE11 Joint 479 Declaration on Data Citation Principles 74 , and are made available under a Creative Commons 480 CC 3.0 BY license. The original datasets are available are linked to from the corresponding SPP 481 datasets using the original repository accession identifiers. These identifiers are for 482 transcriptomic datasets, the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) Series (GSE); and for 483 cistromic/ChIP-Seq datasets, the NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) study identifier (SRP). 484 DOIs for the consensomes and datasets are pending. 485 Code availability 486 The full SPP source code is available in the SPP GitHub account under a Creative Commons 487 CC 3.0 BY license at https://github.com/signaling-pathways-project/ominer/. TABREF0.text: (i) canonical inflammatory signaling pathway nodes with characterized roles in the 121 response to CoV infection, thereby validating the consensome approach in this context; and (ii) evidence for previously uncharacterized transcriptional biology of CoV infection 123 that are consistent with their roles in the response to other viral infections.

TABREF1.text: CC-BY 4.0 International license was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. It is made available under a enzyme node families. Not unexpectedly -and speaking again to validation of the consensomes -the strongest and most significant CoV TC95 overlaps were observed for CC95s for known transcription factor mediators of the transcriptional response to CoV infection, including members of the NFκB (Ludwig & Planz, 2008; Poppe et al., 2017; Ruckle et al., 2012), IRF (Chiang & Liu, 2018) and STAT (Blaszczyk et al., 2016; Frieman et al., 2007; Garcia-Sastre et al., 1998) transcription factor families. Consistent with its known role in the regulation of interferon-stimulated genes (Hasan et al., 2013), we also observed appreciable overlap between the CC95 for TFEB and the ALL CoV TC95. Moreover, the strong overlap between the GTF2B/TFIIB CC95 and all viral TC95s reflects previous evidence identifying GTF2B as a target for orthomyxovirus 153 (Haas et al., 2018), herpes simplex virus (Gelev et al., 2014) and hepatitis B virus
